This is the characteristic of what is to be known, and therefore I will now explain it.
What is meant by all dharmas here?

Namely, the aggregates, sense bases, elements, dependent origination, perfections, grounds, emptiness, factors of enlightenment, noble truths, meditative absorptions, immeasurables, formless attainments, liberations, preliminary practices of meditative absorption, doors of liberation, supernormal powers, dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s, powers, fearlessnesses, unobstructed abilities, great compassion, unique qualities of the Buddha, fruits of the Å›rÄvakas, knowledge of all characteristics, suchness, reality limit, signless dharma realm, and so forth. As for the aggregates, they are the five aggregates.
What are the five?

Here, form refers to the five sense faculties and five sense objects.
The faculties are the eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body.
The objects are form, sound, smell, taste, and touch.

translated: The basis of eye consciousness is the pure eye faculty, the basis of ear consciousness is the pure ear faculty, the basis of nose consciousness is the pure nose faculty, the basis of tongue consciousness is the pure tongue faculty, and the basis of body consciousness is the pure body faculty.
Form is of two kinds: color and shape.
Color refers to blue, etc., shape refers to long, etc.

Sound is of three kinds: that which is derived from the great elements that are appropriated, that which is derived from the great elements that are not appropriated, and that which is derived from the great elements that are both appropriated and not appropriated.
Smell is of two kinds: good smell and bad smell.
Taste is of six kinds: bitter, sour, sweet, pungent, salty, and bland.
Touch is of eleven kinds: solidity, fluidity, heat, motion, heaviness, lightness, smoothness, roughness, softness, hunger, and thirst.
These various touches, when summarized, are of three kinds: agreeable, disagreeable, and neither.

These and other distinctions, such as those arising from the eyes and so forth, or those of the realms, destinies, and so forth, and those of the three times, have boundless divisions and subtle distinctions in their characteristics. One should know that these are briefly explained as the form aggregate.
What is the feeling aggregate?
There are three kinds of feelings, namely, painful feelings, pleasant feelings, and neither painful nor pleasant feelings.

And these three feelings, if distinguished according to the eyes and so forth, have six divisions. They are distinguished in this way, with feelings having eighteen aspects, as will be clearly explained below in the lower realms.

This feeling aggregate, if distinguished according to the realms, destinies, and so forth, has boundless divisions in its characteristics. One should know that these are briefly explained as the feeling aggregate.
What is the perception aggregate?
There are six kinds of perceptions.
The characteristics of these are that, relying on the eyes and so forth, the characteristics of the objects grasped by them are of six kinds.
The characteristics of the objects grasped refer to form and so forth, but the nature of the basis cannot be distinguished.
Whether distinguished or not, it refers to the two dharmas of form and feeling.
These arise from the self-class of the aggregates of self.
As for this aggregate of perception, if distinguished by realms, destinies, etc., it has boundless aspects. One should know that this is a brief explanation of the aggregate of perception.
What is the aggregate of formations?
It refers to the mental factors such as faith, etc., the wholesome factors, and the afflictions such as greed, hatred, and delusion, etc.
Such mental factors arise from the various states of the mind and have aspects that depend on the eyes, etc.
This aggregate of formations, if distinguished by realms, destinies, etc., has boundless aspects. One should know that this is a brief explanation of the aggregate of formations.
What is the aggregate of consciousness?
It refers to the six groups of consciousness.

As for this aggregate of consciousness, if one discriminates based on the eye faculty, etc., and forms, etc., and their characteristics of consciousness, up to the good, bad, indeterminate, etc., with boundless aspects, one should know that this is briefly explained as the aggregate of consciousness.
As previously explained in general, it is called the five aggregates.
As for the so-called bases, they are the twelve bases, namely the six internal bases of the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind;
and the six external bases of form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and dharmas.
Herein, one should know that the five faculties such as the eye and the five objects such as form are the ten bases of form;
As for that mental base, it refers to the various forms of consciousness;
The remaining dharmas are the base of dharmas.
As for the so-called realms, they are the eighteen realms, namely the six faculties, the six objects, and the six consciousnesses.
Herein, the discrimination of the consciousnesses such as the eye and so forth is sixfold, namely the six contacts, i.e., eye contact up to mental contact.
The consciousness of form and so forth has three aspects, namely, wholesome, unwholesome, and neutral.
These aspects are the causal nature of the arising of the three feelings through the contact of the eye and so forth.
Those three feelings arise from the contact of the eye and so forth, totaling six. Each of those six is divided into three kinds, namely, painful, pleasant, and neither painful nor pleasant.
Thus, in total, it is said that contact and feeling each have eighteen.
The aspects of formations are the same as those indicated in the previous aggregate of feeling.
Next, the aspects of earth, water, fire, wind, space, and consciousness, are called the six elements.
What is meant by dependent origination? What are its aspects?
It is the twelve links of dependent origination.
What are the twelve?
Namely, ignorance up to old age and death.

Here, ignorance means, due to incorrect practice regarding karma, fruits, truths, jewels, and dharmas, because of this ignorance, one gives rise to afflictions. Therefore, in the absence of self, one grasps the aggregates and so forth as having attainment.
Ignorance conditions formations, which are of three kinds: meritorious formations, demeritorious formations, and imperturbable formations.

Meritorious formations refer to the ten wholesome courses of action. Demeritorious formations refer to the ten unwholesome courses of action. Imperturbable formations refer to the formless concentrations.
These formations arise due to ignorance as their cause.
Formations condition consciousness, therefore the seeds of the desirable and undesirable fruits of the various consciousnesses such as the eye consciousness grow.
Consciousness conditions name-and-form. This name-and-form is so called because it is designated due to consciousness. Name refers to the place of birth.
Therefore the four aggregates such as feeling are called name, and form is established according to the name.
Name-and-form conditions the six sense bases. Those six sense bases are established by such name-and-form as the eye sense base.
The six sense bases condition contact. Contact refers to the eye, etc. and form, etc., as explained above.
Contact conditions feeling. There are three kinds of feeling, also as explained above. Herein, contact and feeling should be understood as corresponding in aspect.
Feeling is the condition for craving, craving is due to ignorance.
Craving is the condition for grasping, grasping refers to the grasping and arising of pleasure in forms and so forth.
Grasping is the condition for becoming, the characteristics of becoming refer to the characteristics of consciousness and so forth as explained above.

Becoming is the condition for birth, birth refers to the arising of name-and-form, because of that ignorance there are dharmas of birth, and the intrinsic nature of this ignorance is also without distinctions.
Birth is the condition for old age and death, old age refers to the decay of the aggregates, death refers to the destruction of the aggregates.
The end of the dharma of birth is not real, the body that was previously obtained is completely abandoned.

However, that ignorance still continues in the later aggregates, and increases all afflictions and faults. They are all due to the afflictions, karma, and so forth of the same type as ignorance. Therefore, afflictions, karma, and birth arise.
These three are unceasing, and thus the characteristics of cyclic existence continue to flow.
One who knows in this way should give rise to antidotes to real dharmas, understanding that the self-nature of ignorance and so forth is non-self.
In this way, the twelve links of dependent origination are explained in brief.
What are the perfections? What are their characteristics?
There are ten of them.
Among them, there are three kinds of giving: the giving of Dharma, the giving of non-deception, and the giving of kindness.
There are three kinds of morality: the morality of restraining precepts, the morality of embracing wholesome dharmas, and the morality of benefiting sentient beings.
There are three kinds of patience: the patience of contemplating dharmas, the patience of enduring harm from others, and the patience of enduring suffering.
There are three kinds of vigor: the vigor of donning armor, the vigor of practice, and the vigor of ultimate accomplishment.
There are three kinds of meditation: the meditation of being free from faults, the meditation of evoking [samÄdhis], and the meditation of accomplishing tasks.
There are three kinds of wisdom: the wisdom born from hearing, the wisdom born from reflection, and the wisdom born from cultivation.
There are three kinds of skillful means: skillful means for abandoning faults, skillful means for rescuing and delivering, and skillful means for quickly attaining happiness.
There are three kinds of vows: vows for accomplishing one's own practice, vows for liberating sentient beings from bondage, and vows for purifying buddha-lands.
There are three kinds of powers: the power to accomplish tasks, the power to eliminate afflictions, and the power to subdue demons and adversaries.
There are three kinds of wisdom: non-discriminating wisdom, the wisdom of equally realizing discrimination, and the wisdom of eliminating sentient beings' faults.
Thus, the perfections such as giving, with the mind of enlightenment as the forerunner, give rise to the contemplation of loving-kindness towards all sentient beings.
And these perfections, practiced in the world, have no characteristics of practice and also nothing to be attained;
in the supramundane aggregates and so forth, they are the characteristics of selflessness and liberation, truly realized and contemplated in accordance with principle.

As for the so-called grounds, they are the ten grounds, namely the ground of joy, which cultivates the perfection of giving; the ground of removing defilements, which cultivates the perfection of morality; the ground of shining, which cultivates the perfection of patience; the ground of flaming wisdom, which cultivates the perfection of vigor; the ground of overcoming difficulties, which cultivates the perfection of meditation; the ground of manifestation, which cultivates the perfection of wisdom; the ground of far-reaching, which cultivates the perfection of skillful means; the ground of immovability, which cultivates the perfection of vows; the ground of excellent wisdom, which cultivates the perfection of power; and the ground of Dharma clouds, which cultivates the perfection of knowledge.
The principle of non-self that is attained on these grounds is all realized by the mind of kindness, and there are no distinctions.

However, the perfections such as giving that are cultivated are attained through pure and supreme abiding, and the power of vast vows is universally accomplished, not shared by all Å›rÄvakas and others.
These perfections have no distinction in the characteristics of their objects, whether in terms of persons or dharmas, because they are empty of characteristics.
What is called emptiness refers to the eighteen kinds of emptiness, namely, the emptiness of the eyes and so forth, which is called internal emptiness.
The emptiness of forms and so forth is called external emptiness.
The equal observation of the eyes, forms, and so forth is called internal and external emptiness.
The individual observation of the characteristics of the various parts and the world of vessels, all of which are empty, is called great emptiness.
The nature of detachment from grasping and abandoning in all discriminations is called emptiness, and this emptiness is again empty, which is called the emptiness of emptiness.
The observation of the unobtainability in the ultimate truth is called the emptiness of the ultimate truth.
The equality of all conditioned dharmas such as giving and so forth is called the emptiness of conditioned phenomena.
The unarisen characteristics of all unconditioned dharmas are called the emptiness of unconditioned phenomena.
In the dharma of emptiness, there is not a single dharma that can truly be transformed or dispersed without accumulation, which is called the emptiness of dispersion.
All these dharmas are boundless, called boundless emptiness.
In all dharmas, there is not a single dharma that is not empty, called ultimate emptiness.
The self-nature of the aggregates and other dharmas is like this, without arising, apart from one's own grasping and abandoning characteristics, called the emptiness of self-characteristics.
Those dharmas are empty without distinction, called the emptiness of all dharmas.
In the aggregates of the self, grasping and abandoning cannot be obtained, called the emptiness of non-obtainment.
This non-obtainment is because the characteristics of form and so forth cannot be obtained, but there are only the natures of various karmas, called the emptiness of signlessness.
If a person or dharma is empty of its own nature, this is called the emptiness of self-nature.
In the various natures, the nature of grasping and abandoning is absent, called the emptiness of non-nature.
That non-nature is because apart from the aggregates and so forth there is no separate nature;

If apart from the aggregates and so forth one gives rise to discrimination of emptiness in one's own nature, that is the characteristic of obstruction, and is called the emptiness of the self-nature of non-nature.

If one thus discriminates the end of discrimination, one will be able to liberate from the bondage of form and so forth, without further discrimination of having or not having boundless aspects, and be free from grasping and abandoning the aggregates and so forth, which is the one characteristic.
And that one characteristic nature is without duality. Because it is so, one abides in a single object in the perfections.
The principle of emptiness of intrinsic nature is free from the characteristics of conceptual proliferation, which is the true observation of non-self.
As for the factors of enlightenment, there are thirty-seven factors of enlightenment, namely the four establishments of mindfulness up to the eightfold right path.
The four establishments of mindfulness are body, feelings, mind, and dharmas.

As for the establishment of mindfulness of the body here, it is observing the body to be without various accumulations and attachments, free from the characteristics of grasping and abandoning, and so forth, which is called the establishment of mindfulness of the body.
The establishment of mindfulness of feelings, the establishment of mindfulness of the mind, and the establishment of mindfulness of dharmas are also observed in the same way.
Moreover, within this mindfulness of dharmas, if one distinguishes between internal, external, and the middle, there are three kinds, namely, vigor, concentration, and right mindfulness.
These three correspond to the supreme bodhicitta and the wholesome practices such as giving of all bodhisattvas.
Attaining the mark of non-self in all dharmas, this mindfulness is supreme.
Thus, these are called the four establishments of mindfulness in brief. The other dharmas should also be understood in this way.

The four right efforts are what are to be counteracted, not the factors of enlightenment.ğŸ”½That which has already arisen is to be eliminated, and that which has not yet arisen is to be prevented from arising. These are called the two wholesome efforts. What is not to be counteracted, which are the factors of enlightenment;
That which has not yet arisen is to be caused to arise, and that which has already arisen is to be caused to increase and expand. These are called the two wholesome efforts.
Thus, these are called the four right efforts in brief.
The four bases of supernatural power are desire, vigor, concentration, and wisdom.
The fruits obtained through the predominance of such associated practices are observed in relation to objects such as desire, namely the four kinds of samÄdhi.
With body and mind free from all dependence, abiding in the thought of detachment, relying on quiescence and non-action.
This is briefly called the four bases of supernatural power.

The five faculties and five powers are the fruits of understanding all characteristics, namely the predominance of associated faculties and powers such as faith, vigor, mindfulness, concentration, and wisdom.
This is briefly called the five faculties and five powers.
Furthermore, the cultivation of these is the two factors of enlightenment, namely the stages of heat and summit.
In the stage of heat, one cultivates the four establishments of mindfulness, and in the stage of summit, one cultivates the four right efforts.
There are also two superior factors of enlightenment, namely the stage of acceptance and the supreme worldly dharmas.
In the stage of acceptance, one cultivates the four bases of supernatural power, and in the stage of supreme worldly dharmas, one cultivates the five faculties and five powers.
These and other such unconditioned activities are the supreme truth.
The faculties of faith and so forth are the conditions for the path of seeing. The characteristics of practice that should be known are the seven factors of awakening.
The seven factors of awakening are the factor of awakening of mindfulness, up to the factor of awakening of equanimity.
Among them, the factor of awakening of mindfulness is the characteristic of not forgetting the present right mindfulness, the vow to realize awakening for the sake of sentient beings.
The factor of awakening of investigating phenomena is the characteristic of ascertaining the intrinsic nature of my teachings.
The factor of awakening of joy is because one's own cultivation of the path gives rise to the joy and pleasure of the cause of being without outflows.

The factor of awakening of pliancy is because one abandons the seeds that are not factors of awakening according to the true nature of phenomena as they are realized, and because one attains physical and mental pliancy.
The factor of awakening of concentration is the characteristic of the single object of the wisdom that enters suchness, the four immeasurables, and the vow for awakening.

The factor of enlightenment of vigor means that although one contemplates the gate of the supreme qualities of quiescence, one does not become attached to them, and one cultivates all practices without slacking off.

The factor of enlightenment of equanimity means that one thinks of benefiting sentient beings as they should be tamed, and according to their practice of the perfections and other meritorious dharmas, one equally discerns without coming or going, and because one abides in equality.
Thus, these are called the seven factors of enlightenment.

These seven factors of enlightenment are called the factors of right knowledge, and they are able to counteract the characteristics of the afflictive hindrances and the hindrances to that which needs to be known.
One should know that what is cultivated in the path of cultivation is the eightfold right path.
The eightfold right path refers to right view up to right concentration.
Here, right view means understanding the characteristic of no-self in all dharmas and abiding in equality.
The two aspects of the inversions of suffering, etc., are the subtle characteristics observed by supreme wisdom.
Right thought refers to giving rise to thought, not abandoning the causes of what is to be done, and realizing the fruits as wished.
Right speech refers to all speech being free from false discrimination and speaking in accordance with reality.
Right action refers to all activities being free from error, not harming sentient beings, rescuing sentient beings, and so forth, cultivating while free from falsity.
Right livelihood refers to pure livelihood being free from all falsehood and error, practicing what one preaches, and realizing it oneself.
Right effort refers to even though one has reached the highest stage, one still makes progress, the body being free from fatigue and the mind being courageous and resolute.

Right mindfulness refers to contemplating the foundations of mindfulness and so forth in accordance with reality, adorning one's own vows with a mind of loving-kindness, and not forgetting anything among all dharmas.

Right concentration refers to bodily and other activities always relying on the most excellent merits, abiding in non-discriminating cognition, and being in accord with the characteristics of equality of all meditative absorptions.
